chapter.title: Annotation Support
chapter.para: We strongly believe in the POJO programming model. Furthermore, the goal of the Axon Framework is to relieve you of any plumbing and boilerplate coding. The annotation support features of Axon allow you to build plain event listeners (just extending object) and annotating the relevant event handling methods with @EventHandler.

sect1.title: Creating an annotated event handler
sect1.para: Creating an annotated event listener is pretty easy. You don't need to extend any special classes. All you need to do is annotate any methods that you want called when en event comes in with the @EventHandler annotation.

There are, however, a few rules for these methods:
The method must accept 1 or 2 parameters. The first parameter must be a subtype of DomainEvent. The second (optional) parameter is of type TransactionStatus. See .
Return values are allowed, but are ignored by dispatchers. Exceptions are highly discouraged, and are likely to be caught and ignored by the dispatchers

Once the annotation bean post processor (AnnotationEventListenerBeanPostProcessor) is defined in the spring application context, all you need to to is add the bean definitions of your annotated event listeners to the context. That's it.
Alternatively, you can wrap each annotated bean in a AnnotationEventListenerAdapter.
